results.title: The Buzz of rock and roll
results.creator_credit: Dale Lynch and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: Documentary about three Australian musicians who are also tinnitus sufferers- Fiona Horne (DefFX), Rod Ling (July Fourteenth) and Richard Pleasance (Boom Crash Opera). Tinnitus is a condition that causes ringing in the ears and affects one in five people.

results.title: The Butler
results.creator_credit: Anna Kannava, John Cruthers and Huzzah Productions
results.brief_description: An intimate portrait of a Greek family and their experience of migration and integration into Australian life. Nino, the youngest, is the vehicle used to explore the alienation and shock that are part of migration, the complexity of family relationships and the integration of the intellectually disabled into the community. “The Butler” is the sequel to “Ten years after, ten years older” also held in the collection.

results.title: The Business of newspapers
results.brief_description: A comprehensive film examining the past present and future of the newspaper business. Issues covered include the influence of big businesses on journalism, the crisis of the survival of small-town newspapers, and how a newspaper’s editorial policies are being dictated by economic consideration. NB: The information in this film is very relevant to Australian media ownership in the 90’s.

results.title: The Bush myth
results.brief_description: This documentary is an examination of the way the bush myth has been portrayed in such Australian films as “The Sentimental Bloke”, “Sons of Matthew”, “Sunday too far away”, and “Picnic at Hanging Rock”. It covers the use of the bush motif throughout Australian history and how the interpretations and reactions to the landscape have changed so rapidly. It studies how the theme of nature versus culture has goverened almost all film making depicting the Australian bush until approximately 1982.

results.title: The Burning issue
results.brief_description: A dramatization about a magazine writer covering a major forest fire in the South. His angle…to make his public understand just how important their forests are, and why they must be saved. Shows many dramatic fires and firefighting scenes.

results.title: The Burke and Wills Expedition 1860-1861 (MAC & PC)
results.creator_credit: David Corke and Educational Media International
results.brief_description: Film producer and author David Corke, first presents the traditional story, then invites us to examine the original historic sources. How did Burke and Wills really die? Does the legend depicted in the story, film and pictures fit the facts? Includes multi-level presentations and commentary, historic diary extracts, articles and documents, useful and informative maps, facts about other famous Australian explorers and a detailed study guide with student activities.

results.title: The Bullets of the poets
results.creator_credit: Gabrielle Dalton, George Gittoes, Gittoes and Dalton Productions and Gultha
results.brief_description: For the last decade in Nicaragua, women have been at the frontline of fighting and won the respect of their male companions both as organisers and combatants. Women have brought about this revolutionary change in attitudes by freeing themselves of the stereotype conventions regarding the place of women in war. The six women profiled in the film are remarkable for their sensitivity and the candidness with which they tell their stories. Though they have all experienced the horror of war, none have been hardened. They release their deepest feelings through poetry, and identify more with humanitarian idealism than political ideologies. Filmed entirely on location in Nicaragua.

results.title: The Building of Florence Cathedral
results.creator_credit: Mary Hoskins and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Shows how, by examining works of art, it is possible to learn much about the society that produced them, with particular reference to the building of the Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore in renaissance Florence. Commentary by John Larner.
